question: Question_02
statement:
Let $\displaystyle k \in \mathbb{N}$,
$\displaystyle a_{0},a_{1},...,a_{k} \in \mathbb{R}$ with
$\displaystyle a_{k}\neq 0$. If
$\displaystyle f : \mathbb{N} \to \mathbb{R}$ given by

\begin{align*}\displaystyle f(n) = a_{k}n^{k} + a_{k-1}n^{k-1} + ... + a_{1}n + a_{0}\end{align*}

is a multiplicative function, show that $\displaystyle a_{k}=1$ and that
$\displaystyle a_{i} = 0$ for $\displaystyle 0 \leq i < k$.
sols:
First we show that $\displaystyle a_{k} = 1$. Let $\displaystyle \ell$
be an integer. Since our function is multiplicative, we know that

$\displaystyle f(10^{\ell}) = f(2^{\ell})f(5^{\ell})$.

Expanding gives

\begin{align*}
a_{k}10^{\ell k} + a_{k-1}10^{\ell(k-1)} + ... + a_{0} &= 
(a_{k}2^{\ell k} + a_{k-1}2^{\ell(k-1)} + ... + a_{0})(a_{k}5^{\ell k} + a_{k-1}5^{\ell(k-1)} + ... + a_{0})\\
&= a_{k}^{2}10^{\ell k} + a_{k-1}10^{\ell(k-1)}((2 + 5)a_{k} + a_{k-1}) + .. + a_{0}^{2}\end{align*}

Isolating for $\displaystyle 10^{\ell k}$ gives

$\displaystyle a_{k}(1-a_{k})10^{\ell k} = a_{k-1}10^{\ell(k-1)}((2 + 5)a_{k} + a_{k-1}-1) + ... + a_{0}^{2}-a_{0}$

Dividing both sides by $\displaystyle 10^{\ell k}$ gives

$\displaystyle a_{k}(1-a_{k}) = 10^{-\ell} (a_{k-1}((2 + 5)a_{k} + a_{k-1}-1) + ... + (a_{0}^{2}-a_{0})10^{-\ell(k-1)})$

Making $\displaystyle \ell$ sufficiently large, we can see that the
right hand side tends to 0. Since the left hand side is an integer, we
see that the right hand side must in fact be 0 and hence so must the
left hand side. Thus,

$\displaystyle a_{k}(1-a_{k}) = 0$

giving $\displaystyle a_{k} = 1$ since $\displaystyle a_{k} \neq 0$ as
stated in the question.

Next, we show that all the other coefficients must be 0. Let \emph{j} be
the largest index less that \emph{k} such that
$\displaystyle a_{j} \neq 0$. We assume that \emph{j} exists and find a
contradiction. Thus,

$\displaystyle f(n) = x^{k} + a_{j}x^{j} + ... + a_{0}$.

Let \emph{m} and \emph{n} be arbitrary nonzero, nonunital positive
integers such that $\displaystyle \gcd(m,n)=1$. Then, we see again that

$\displaystyle f((mn)^{\ell}) = f(m^{\ell})f(n^{\ell})$

and hence

\begin{align*}
(mn)^{\ell k} + a_{j}(mn)^{\ell j} + ... + a_{0} &= 
(m^{\ell k} + a_{j}m^{\ell j } + ... + a_{0})(n^{\ell k} + a_{j}n^{\ell j} + ... + a_{0})\\
&= (mn)^{\ell k} + a_{j}(mn)^{\ell j}(m^{\ell(k-j)} + n^{\ell(k-j)} + a_{j}) + .. + a_{0}^{2}\end{align*}

Cancelling and isolating for $\displaystyle a_{j}$ yields

\begin{align*}
a_{j}(mn)^{\ell j}(1 - m^{\ell(k-j)}-n^{\ell(k-j)} - a_{j}) = 
\text{terms with order less than } (mn)^{\ell j}\end{align*}

As before dividing by $\displaystyle (mn)^{\ell j}$ and letting
$\displaystyle \ell$ tend to infinity shows that the modified right hand
side is 0 and thus, we have

$\displaystyle a_{j}(mn)^{\ell j}(1 - m^{\ell(k-j)}-n^{\ell(k-j)} - a_{j}) = 0$

Hence, either $\displaystyle a_{j} = 0$ or
$\displaystyle a_{j} = 1 - m^{\ell(k-j)} n^{\ell(k-j)}$. However,
$\displaystyle a_{j}$ is completely independent of $\displaystyle \ell$.
Thus as \emph{j} is distinct from \emph{k} (so
$\displaystyle k-j \neq 0$), we must have that $\displaystyle a_{j}=0$
which shows that no such \emph{j} can exists. Hence each and every
$\displaystyle a_{j}$ for $\displaystyle 0 \leq j < k$ must in fact be
0. This completes the proof.

Keep in mind that $\displaystyle f(1) = 1$ and this holds with this
polynomial. Also it is clear that $\displaystyle f(n) = n^{k}$ is
multiplicative.
hints:
Argue using the fact that

$\displaystyle f((mn)^{\ell}) = f(m^{\ell})f(n^{\ell})$

where $\displaystyle \gcd(m,n) = 1$. Your proof should also have a feel
of analysis in it.
